title: About Me
text: I am a PhD candidate in Political Science at the University of Western Ontario. My research focuses on political psychology and public opinion, with an emphasis on political cognition. I am particularly curious about the ways people learn about politics and the kinds of knowledge they mobilize when thinking about politics. The research I’m working on for my dissertation examines how belief structures interact with cultural contexts to shape political behaviour and identities. I love teaching and finding new methods of transmitting knowledge in more engaging and effective ways. Research gives me the opportunity to spend time with puzzles and learn a little more about the world everyday; it’s not always smooth sailing, but it’s still sailing.

Interactive Teaching Tools
I’ve developed a series of interactive tutorials using R Shiny that help students visualize and understand complex statistical and methodological concepts. These applications provide hands-on learning experiences that complement traditional lecture formats.

Featured Tutorial:




Screenshot of Regression Analysis Tutorial



This interactive application allows students to explore the basics of regression analysis, including assumptions, coefficient interpretation, and diagnostics.
Access the Regression Analysis Tutorial
Features:

Interactive quizzes stimulate learning through recall and repeated exposure to important concepts.
A mix of conceptual, logical, and practical tasks mobilize the different types of knowledge students need for statistical analysis
Complete-the-code tasks train students on the hands-on skills they need to go from raw data to analytic products

title: Hugo Machado
text:
Current Research

Dissertation Project
Associative Diffusion and Belief System Consolidation: How Cultural Meanings Shape Political Identities in Contemporary Democracies
University of Western Ontario
My dissertation is focused on understanding how different cultural and informational environments lead to variation in the content and structure of political schemas. This research:

Investigates the interaction between political identity formation and cultural influences
Explores how belief structures mediate political behaviour
Employs mixed methods including surveys and experimental approaches

I am currently developing this research under the supervision of Dr. Mathieu Turgeon.

Change in Predicted Probabilities for Repressive Preferences (Cannabis)



This visualization shows how different individual characteristics and psychological traits affect support for repressive cannabis policies. Points to the right of the vertical dotted line indicate factors that increase support for repressive policies, while points to the left indicate factors that decrease support. Data from the 2019 Canadian Election Study (Stephenson, Harell, Rubenson, Loewen, 2020)
